The small index property for homogeneous models in AEC’s

1. Introduction

The role of automorphism groups of mathematical structures and their connections to their theories and bi-interpretation classes has been an active research area in model theory in the past two decades. The main theme has been to investigate what kind of information from the structure can be recovered from its group of automorphisms (the reconstruction problem). The automorphism groups are also topological groups, in a natural way (pointwise convergence topology). The reconstruction problem is therefore linked to both the purely algebraic aspects of the groups A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M), as well as to their topological aspects. The crucial property linking these two aspects is the “small index property”, the center of study of this paper. A structure M𝑀M of cardinality κ𝜅\kappa has the small index property (SIP) if every subgroup H≤A​u​t​(M)𝐻𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀H\leq Aut(M) of small index (that is, such that [Aut(M):H]<|Aut(M)|\left[Aut\left(M\right):H\right]<\left|Aut\left(M\right)\right|) is open in A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M).

Although in principle the SIP is posed in terms of a (first-order) structure M𝑀M, previous results have relied heavily on the first order theory of M𝑀M and its bi-interpretability class. The structural properties revealed by A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M) depend somehow more on the theory of M𝑀M, on the structural properties around M𝑀M, than on M𝑀M taken in isolation. In this article, we look for the first time at the situation of a structure M𝑀M that may fail to be saturated yet still have a good reconstruction problem, provided by other structural properties:

  • •

    homogeneity,

  • •

    being inside an abstract elementary class (AEC) and

  • •

    having a strong amalgamation property (for strong embeddings in the abstract elementary class, and for automorphisms).

These properties are isolated by carefully checking the case studied before by Lascar and Shelah [7], where they prove the SIP for uncountable, saturated structures, relying on their first order theories. In this paper we show that their techniques may be adapted to our more general setup: saturation is weakened to homogeneity, and we isolate a strong notion of amalgamation in AECs that suffices to replace the technical aspects of the proof from [7] that depend on the first order theory of the structure. So, our result shows that the SIP may be obtained for homogeneous structures, provided they are placed in an AEC that has enough structural properties111Classical model theory deals with mathematical structures using tools of first-order logic; the first-order setting provides many technical tools to study them. However, the first-order setting has some limitations: many classes of mathematical structures are not first-order axiomatizable, and even when they are, there are situations in which a “non-elementary” model theoretical analysis results in better regularity properties. Shelah in [9] introduced the notion of Abstract Elementary Classes (AECs), where logic and syntax are set aside and the elements of the class are axiomatized using an abstract notion of “strong” embedding (important examples of these classes include Zilber’s pseudo-exponentiation, various pseudo-analytic expansions of the complex numbers and several instances of covers - more recently, modular functions have been successfully analyzed using these tools - see [5]). In this general setting, we do not necessarily need to consider the elements of the class in the framework of the first-order logic and work with formulas. However, many important concepts of model theory such as types, forking and other independence notions have been successfully studied in the AEC context..

An important step in reconstruction problems is therefore determining whether a structure has the SIP: this property is a key piece in the recovery of the topological structure of the automorphism group from its pure group structure. The SIP has been proved for a number of countable first-order structures. With the pointwise convergence topology, in the first-order case, the automorphism groups of countable structures are actually Polish groups (see [4] for more details). Indeed, the automorphism groups of countable structures being Polish is a very useful fact that can provide many technical tools to prove properties like SIP. For the uncountable first-order structures, we do not have access to such tools, however still nice properties can be proven: In the uncountable case, with some cardinal restrictions, Lascar and Shelah in [7] proved that the automorphism group of an uncountable saturated model has SIP.

In this paper, we prove the following theorem (Theorem 4.1 in this paper, see section 4):

Theorem.

Let M𝑀M be a homogeneous model in an abstract elementary class (K,≼𝒦)𝐾subscriptprecedes-or-equals𝒦\left(K,\preccurlyeq_{\mathcal{K}}\right) such that |M|=κ>LS​(K)𝑀𝜅LS𝐾\left|M\right|=\kappa>\mbox{LS}\left(K\right) and κ<κ=κsuperscript𝜅absent𝜅𝜅\kappa^{<\kappa}=\kappa. Furthermore, assume that 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) is a strong amalgamation class. Consider the group A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M) with the topology given by 𝔗clsuperscript𝔗cl\mathfrak{T}^{\mbox{cl}}, and let H⩽Aut​(M)𝐻Aut𝑀H\leqslant\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) be such that [Aut(M):H]≤κ\left[\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right):H\right]\leq\kappa. Then, H𝐻H is an open subgroup of A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M); i.e., there exists A∈𝒦<​(M)𝐴superscript𝒦𝑀A\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) such that AutA​(M)⩽HsubscriptAut𝐴𝑀𝐻\mathrm{Aut}_{A}\left(M\right)\leqslant H.

In other words, (Aut​(M),𝔗cl)Aut𝑀superscript𝔗cl\left(\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right),\mathfrak{T}^{\mbox{cl}}\right) has the small index property.

This theorem provides a purely algebraic framework for a model to have the small index property; we thereby transfer in a rather sharp way the Lascar-Shelah setting [7], where a similar result is proved for saturated uncountable models of a first order theory.

In the last two sections, we study some examples and applications: we prove the SIP for the Zilber field (see [12, 6, 2]), we study the SIP for the j𝑗j-mapping (modular invariant) under the light of recent results in its model theory, and for various other Lω1,ωsubscript𝐿subscript𝜔1𝜔L_{\omega_{1},\omega}-axiomatizable structures.

The authors thank the referee for several questions and remarks that have helped improve the presentation of our results.

2. Setting

We fix two infinite cardinals λ,κ𝜆𝜅\lambda,\kappa such that λ<κ𝜆𝜅\lambda<\kappa and κ<κ=κsuperscript𝜅absent𝜅𝜅\kappa^{<\kappa}=\kappa. We work within a fixed AEC 𝒦=(K,≺𝒦)𝒦𝐾subscriptprecedes𝒦\mathcal{K}=\left(K,\prec_{\mathcal{K}}\right) with LS​(𝒦)≤λLS𝒦𝜆\mbox{LS}\left(\mathcal{K}\right)\leq\lambda. We now provide some notation and definitions.

For the rest of the paper we fix a homogeneous model M∈K𝑀𝐾M\in K of size κ𝜅\kappa (we use “homogeneous” in the following precise sense: all isomorphisms between small strong substructures of M𝑀M, f:N1→N2:𝑓→subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2f:N_{1}\to N_{2} for N1,N2∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2superscript𝒦𝑀N_{1},N_{2}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}(M), can be extended to automorphisms of M𝑀M). All our results from here on refer to properties of M𝑀M within the AEC 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}.

In our context, “small” (subset or submodel) means “of cardinality <κabsent𝜅<\kappa”.

We may even say that our focus of study is the part of 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} “below M𝑀M”, i.e. the class of small 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}-elementary submodels of M𝑀M. In this sense the actual arena of our results is the class (𝒦<​(M),≺𝒦)superscript𝒦𝑀subscriptprecedes𝒦\left(\mathcal{K}^{<}(M),\prec_{\mathcal{K}}\right). This is almost an AEC; the only property of an AEC this fails to satisfy is the unions axiom. In recent years, weak AECs have been studied; this class is one of them.

Our notion of homogeneity means precisely that 𝒪fM≠∅superscriptsubscript𝒪𝑓𝑀\mathcal{O}_{f}^{M}\neq\emptyset for all f∈Iso​(N1;N2)𝑓Isosubscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2f\in\mbox{Iso}\left(N_{1};N_{2}\right) with N1,N2∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2superscript𝒦𝑀N_{1},N_{2}\in\mathcal{K^{<}}\left(M\right) when we translate the concept to this notation.

Remark 2.1.

Let N∈𝒦<​(M)𝑁superscript𝒦𝑀N\in\mathcal{K^{<}}\left(M\right). Then the restriction map πN:Aut{N}​(M)→Aut​(N):subscript𝜋𝑁→subscriptAut𝑁𝑀Aut𝑁\pi_{N}:\mathrm{Aut}_{\left\{N\right\}}\left(M\right)\rightarrow\mathrm{Aut}\left(N\right) is surjective: if f∈A​u​t​(N)𝑓𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑁f\in Aut(N) then there is f′∈A​u​t​(M)superscript𝑓′𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀f^{\prime}\in Aut(M) such that f=f′↾N=N𝑓superscript𝑓′↾𝑁𝑁f=f^{\prime}\upharpoonright N=N.

Definition 2.2.

Remark 2.3.

This notion of closure appeared in [1] in connection with the study of the failure of tameness. It is worth noting here that with this notion of closure, unlike in other related constructions, closures do not necessarily belong to the class 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}. Moreover, note that if A⊆M𝐴𝑀A\subseteq M and clM​(A)≠Msuperscriptcl𝑀𝐴𝑀\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right)\neq M, then for every m∈M\clM​(A)𝑚\𝑀superscriptcl𝑀𝐴m\in M\backslash\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right) there is N≼𝒦Msubscriptprecedes-or-equals𝒦𝑁𝑀N\preccurlyeq_{\mathcal{K}}M such that m∉N𝑚𝑁m\notin N and clM​(A)⊆Nsuperscriptcl𝑀𝐴𝑁\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right)\subseteq N.

It is easy to see that the following holds.

  1. (1)

    clM​(N)=Nsuperscriptcl𝑀𝑁𝑁\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(N\right)=N for all N∈K𝑁𝐾N\in K with N≼𝒦Msubscriptprecedes-or-equals𝒦𝑁𝑀N\preccurlyeq_{\mathcal{K}}M.

  2. (2)

    clM​(clM​(A))=clM​(A)superscriptcl𝑀superscriptcl𝑀𝐴superscriptcl𝑀𝐴\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right)\right)=\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right) for all A⊆M𝐴𝑀A\subseteq M.

Remark 2.4.

The definition above of clMsuperscriptcl𝑀\mbox{cl}^{M} generalizes the first order definition of the algebraic closure acl with ≼𝒦subscriptprecedes-or-equals𝒦\preccurlyeq_{\mathcal{K}} as elementary submodel.

Fact 2.5.

    Suppose A⊂M𝐴𝑀A\subset M, then |clM​(A)|≤|A|+L​S​(K)superscriptcl𝑀𝐴𝐴𝐿𝑆𝐾\left|\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right)\right|\leq\left|A\right|+LS\left(K\right).

Proof.

We extend the two notations that we have defined before from elements of 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}(M) to all closed sets.

Definition 2.6.

and Aut​(X):=Iso​(X;X)assignAut𝑋Iso𝑋𝑋\mathrm{Aut}\left(X\right):=\mbox{Iso}\left(X;X\right).

Corollary 2.7.

The set {AutX​(M):X∈𝒞}conditional-setsubscriptAut𝑋𝑀𝑋𝒞\left\{\mathrm{Aut}_{X}\left(M\right):X\in\mathcal{C}\right\} forms a basis of open neighborhoods of identity.

Let 𝔗clsuperscript𝔗cl\mathfrak{T}^{\mbox{cl}} be the topology that is generated by the cosets of stabilizers A​u​tX​(M)𝐴𝑢subscript𝑡𝑋𝑀Aut_{X}(M) for X∈𝒞𝑋𝒞X\in\mathcal{C}. This is the setup for the proof of our main theorem (see section 4).

Remark 2.8.

Similarly to the countable case in first-order logic we have the following property: Suppose M𝑀M and N𝑁N are two models of the same uncountable cardinality and we topologize them in the same way. Suppose α:Aut​(M)→Aut​(N):𝛼→Aut𝑀Aut𝑁\alpha:\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right)\rightarrow\mathrm{Aut}\left(N\right) is an embedding as abstract groups. Then the S​I​P𝑆𝐼𝑃SIP for M𝑀M implies that α𝛼\alpha is continuous.

2.2. Some properties of the class of closed sets 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}

In this subsection we do not require the assumption that M𝑀M is homogeneous.

Lemma 2.9.

Let X,Y∈𝒞𝑋𝑌𝒞X,Y\in\mathcal{C} and f∈Iso​(X;Y)𝑓Iso𝑋𝑌f\in\mbox{Iso}\left(X;Y\right) be such that 𝒪fM≠∅superscriptsubscript𝒪𝑓𝑀\mathcal{O}_{f}^{M}\neq\emptyset. Then, there exists Z∈𝒞𝑍𝒞Z\in\mathcal{C} and f′∈Aut​(Z)superscript𝑓′Aut𝑍f^{\prime}\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(Z\right) such that X∪Y⊆Z𝑋𝑌𝑍X\cup Y\subseteq Z , f⩽f′𝑓superscript𝑓′f\leqslant f^{\prime} and 𝒪f′M≠∅superscriptsubscript𝒪superscript𝑓′𝑀\mathcal{O}_{f^{\prime}}^{M}\neq\emptyset.

Let X1:=N∪σ​[N]∪σ−1​[N]assignsubscript𝑋1𝑁𝜎delimited-[]𝑁superscript𝜎1delimited-[]𝑁X_{1}:=N\cup\sigma\left[N\right]\cup\sigma^{-1}\left[N\right] and let λ=|X1|𝜆subscript𝑋1\lambda=\left|X_{1}\right|. Corollary 2.10.

Let σ∈Aut​(M)𝜎Aut𝑀\sigma\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) and assume λ𝜆\lambda is a cardinal with L​S​(K)≤λ<κ𝐿𝑆𝐾𝜆𝜅LS\left(K\right)\leq\lambda<\kappa, then there exists N∈𝒦<​(M)𝑁superscript𝒦𝑀N\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) with |N|=λ𝑁𝜆\left|N\right|=\lambda such that σ↾N∈Aut​(N)↾𝜎𝑁Aut𝑁\sigma\upharpoonright N\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(N\right).

Proof.

We use the same argument as the proof of Lemma 2.9: start with N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} and build up a ≺Ksubscriptprecedes𝐾\prec_{K}-increasing chain of models Nnsubscript𝑁𝑛N_{n} such that Nn⊇Xn:=Nn−1∪σ​[Nn−1]∪σ−1​[Nn−1]superset-of-or-equalssubscript𝑁𝑛subscript𝑋𝑛assignsubscript𝑁𝑛1𝜎delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑛1superscript𝜎1delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑛1N_{n}\supseteq X_{n}:=N_{n-1}\cup\sigma\left[N_{n-1}\right]\cup\sigma^{-1}\left[N_{n-1}\right]. ∎

Remark 2.11.

So far, no special properties of κ𝜅\kappa as a cardinality have been used. For the next corollary we use κ<ω=κsuperscript𝜅absent𝜔𝜅\kappa^{<\omega}=\kappa.

Corollary 2.12.

Let I𝐼I be an index set with |I|<κ𝐼𝜅\left|I\right|<\kappa. Assume fi∈I​s​o​(Xi;Yi)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐼𝑠𝑜subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖f_{i}\in Iso\left(X_{i};Y_{i}\right) with Xi,Yi∈𝒞subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖𝒞X_{i},Y_{i}\in\mathcal{C} are such that 𝒪fiM≠∅superscriptsubscript𝒪subscript𝑓𝑖𝑀\mathcal{O}_{f_{i}}^{M}\not=\emptyset, for i∈I𝑖𝐼i\in I. Corollary 2.13.

Let I𝐼I be an index set with |I|=λ𝐼𝜆\left|I\right|=\lambda such that L​S​(K)≤λ<κ𝐿𝑆𝐾𝜆𝜅LS\left(K\right)\leq\lambda<\kappa. 3. Generic sequences of automorphisms

This section sets up the tools for the main proof: generic sequences of automorphisms and strong amalgamation bases. We provide the basic notions (the first one is adapted from [7] to our context, the second one is new) and then derive the existence of large families of generic sequences of automorphisms.

Definition 3.1.

Suppose M0,M1,M2∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2superscript𝒦𝑀M_{0},M_{1},M_{2}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) and M0≺𝒦Misubscriptprecedes𝒦subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀𝑖M_{0}\prec_{\mathcal{K}}M_{i} for i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2. Let γ​0𝛾0\gamma\text{\textsuperscript{0}} be a sequence of automorphisms of M0subscript𝑀0M_{0}. Assume γ1superscript𝛾1\gamma^{1} and γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2} are sequences of automorphisms of M1subscript𝑀1M_{1} and M2subscript𝑀2M_{2}; respectively, both extending γ0superscript𝛾0\gamma^{0}. We say γ​¹𝛾¹\gamma\text{\textonesuperior} and γ​²𝛾²\gamma\text{\texttwosuperior} are compatible over M0subscript𝑀0M_{0} if there exist M3∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑀3superscript𝒦𝑀M_{3}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) and α1,α2∈AutM0​(M)subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2subscriptAutsubscript𝑀0𝑀\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2}\in\mathrm{Aut}_{M_{0}}\left(M\right) such that α1​[M1],α2​[M2]≺𝒦M3subscriptprecedes𝒦subscript𝛼1delimited-[]subscript𝑀1subscript𝛼2delimited-[]subscript𝑀2subscript𝑀3\alpha_{1}\left[M_{1}\right],\alpha_{2}\left[M_{2}\right]\prec_{\mathcal{K}}M_{3} and γ3∈Aut​(M3)superscript𝛾3Autsubscript𝑀3\gamma^{3}\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(M_{3}\right) extends both α1∘γ1∘α1−1↾α1​[M1]↾subscript𝛼1superscript𝛾1superscriptsubscript𝛼11subscript𝛼1delimited-[]subscript𝑀1\alpha_{1}\circ\gamma^{1}\circ\alpha_{1}^{-1}\restriction\alpha_{1}\left[M_{1}\right] and α2∘γ2∘α2−1↾α2​[M2]↾subscript𝛼2superscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝛼21subscript𝛼2delimited-[]subscript𝑀2\alpha_{2}\circ\gamma^{2}\circ\alpha_{2}^{-1}\restriction\alpha_{2}\left[M_{2}\right] (this is equivalent to requiring that γ3∘α1↾N1=α1∘γ1↾superscript𝛾3subscript𝛼1subscript𝑁1subscript𝛼1superscript𝛾1\gamma^{3}\circ\alpha_{1}\restriction N_{1}=\alpha_{1}\circ\gamma^{1} and γ3∘α2↾N2=α2∘γ2↾superscript𝛾3subscript𝛼2subscript𝑁2subscript𝛼2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{3}\circ\alpha_{2}\restriction N_{2}=\alpha_{2}\circ\gamma^{2}).

Notice that in the definition above for a sequence of automorphisms we allow repetitions of automorphisms.

We now define a central notion in the proof of the main theorem: generic sequences of automorphisms (and the particular case of a generic automorphism).

Definition 3.2.

Suppose I𝐼I is an index set with |I|<κ𝐼𝜅\left|I\right|<\kappa and let γ=(gi:i∈I)\gamma=\left(g_{i}:i\in I\right) be a sequence of automorphisms of M𝑀M. We say γ𝛾\gamma is a generic sequence of automorphisms if whenever N∈𝒦<​(M)𝑁superscript𝒦𝑀N\in\mathcal{\mathcal{K}}^{<}\left(M\right) is such that γ↾N↾𝛾𝑁\gamma\upharpoonright N is a sequence of automorphisms of N𝑁N and N1∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁1superscript𝒦𝑀N_{1}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) is such that N≺𝒦N1subscriptprecedes𝒦𝑁subscript𝑁1N\prec_{\mathcal{K}}N_{1} and θ=(ti:i∈I)\theta=\left(t_{i}:i\in I\right) is a sequence of automorphisms of N1subscript𝑁1N_{1} extending γ↾N↾𝛾𝑁\gamma\upharpoonright N (i.e. gi↾N⩽ti↾subscript𝑔𝑖𝑁subscript𝑡𝑖g_{i}\upharpoonright N\leqslant t_{i} for all i∈I𝑖𝐼i\in I), then if γ↾N′↾𝛾superscript𝑁′\gamma\upharpoonright N^{\prime} and θ𝜃\theta are compatible over N𝑁N for some N′∈𝒦<​(M)superscript𝑁′superscript𝒦𝑀N^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right), there exists α∈AutN​(M)𝛼subscriptAut𝑁𝑀\alpha\in\mathrm{Aut}_{N}\left(M\right) such that γ𝛾\gamma extends α∘θ∘α−1𝛼𝜃superscript𝛼1\alpha\circ\theta\circ\alpha^{-1} (or equivalently γα:=(giα:i∈I)\gamma^{\alpha}:=\left(g_{i}^{\alpha}:i\in I\right) extends θ𝜃\theta).

We abuse language by saying that “g𝑔g is a generic automorphism” when γ=(g)𝛾𝑔\gamma=\left(g\right) is a constant generic sequence of automorphisms.

Remark 3.3.

Suppose I𝐼I is an index set with |I|<κ𝐼𝜅\left|I\right|<\kappa and let γ=(gi:i∈I)\gamma=\left(g_{i}:i\in I\right) be generic. Then γαsuperscript𝛾𝛼\gamma^{\alpha} is generic for α∈Aut​(M)𝛼Aut𝑀\alpha\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right).

It is an interesting question to determine sufficient conditions for a generic sequence of automorphisms to exist. We now provide one condition that will guarantee precisely that.

Definition 3.5.

Assume I𝐼I is an index set with cardinality less than κ𝜅\kappa. Suppose N0∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁0superscript𝒦𝑀N_{0}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) and γ0=(gi0:i∈I)\gamma^{0}=\left(g_{i}^{0}:i\in I\right) is a sequence of automorphisms of N0subscript𝑁0N_{0}. We say (N0,γ0)subscript𝑁0superscript𝛾0\left(N_{0},\gamma^{0}\right) is a strong amalgamation base if for all N1,N2∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2superscript𝒦𝑀N_{1},N_{2}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) with N0≺𝒦N1,N2subscriptprecedes𝒦subscript𝑁0subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2N_{0}\prec_{\mathcal{K}}N_{1},N_{2}; all γ1superscript𝛾1\gamma^{1} and γ2superscript𝛾2\gamma^{2} sequences of automorphisms of N1subscript𝑁1N_{1} and N2subscript𝑁2N_{2} that extend γ​0𝛾0\gamma\text{\textsuperscript{0}}; respectively, are compatible over N0subscript𝑁0N_{0}. We say 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) is a strong amalgamation class if (N,γ)𝑁𝛾\left(N,\gamma\right) is a strong amalgamation base for every N∈𝑁absentN\in 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) and γ=(gi:i∈I)\gamma=\left(g_{i}:i\in I\right) a sequence of automorphisms of N𝑁N.

Remark.

As we see next, this notion guarantees the existence of generic sequences of automorphisms. Its importance lies in the fact of being able to “amalgamate coherently” sequences of isomorphisms, while also doing an amalgam of the domains!

Lemma 3.6.

Suppose 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) is a strong amalgamation class. Then generic sequences of automorphisms with index set of arbitrary cardinality less than κ𝜅\kappa exist.

Proof.

We write the proof for the case when I​ is a singleton𝐼 is a singletonI\text{ is a singleton}. The proof for the general case (arbitrary I𝐼I) is not essentially different, but is more cumbersome; therefore we address here only the case when the sequence consists of a single automorphism.

We will build a generic automorphism f𝑓f as the union of a tower of automorphisms of some elements of 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}(M).     If i𝑖i is a limit ordinal then let Mi=⋃β<iMβsubscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑀𝛽M_{i}=\bigcup_{\beta<i}M_{\beta} and fi=⋃β<ifβsubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝑓𝛽f_{i}=\bigcup_{\beta<i}f_{\beta}; note that the cardinal assumption κ<κ=κsuperscript𝜅absent𝜅𝜅\kappa^{<\kappa}=\kappa implies that Mi∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑀𝑖superscript𝒦𝑀M_{i}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right).

Since N1subscript𝑁1N_{1} is an strong amalgamation base, there is N2∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁2superscript𝒦𝑀N_{2}\in\mathcal{K^{<}}\left(M\right) and e2∈Aut​(N2)subscript𝑒2Autsubscript𝑁2e_{2}\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(N_{2}\right) such that Mi,α​[N]≺𝒦N2subscriptprecedes𝒦subscript𝑀𝑖𝛼delimited-[]𝑁subscript𝑁2M_{i},\alpha\left[N\right]\prec_{\mathcal{K}}N_{2}, f′⩽e2superscript𝑓′subscript𝑒2f^{\prime}\leqslant e_{2}, α∈AutN1​(M)𝛼subscriptAutsubscript𝑁1𝑀\alpha\in\mathrm{Aut}_{N_{1}}\left(M\right) and α∘g∘α−1⩽e2𝛼𝑔superscript𝛼1subscript𝑒2\alpha\circ g\circ\alpha^{-1}\leqslant e_{2}. It is clear that (N2,e2)∈Esubscript𝑁2subscript𝑒2𝐸\left(N_{2},e_{2}\right)\in E , then the construction of f𝑓f guarantees that there is j>i𝑗𝑖j>i such that (N2,e2)subscript𝑁2subscript𝑒2\left(N_{2},e_{2}\right) embeds into (Mj,fj)subscript𝑀𝑗subscript𝑓𝑗\left(M_{j},f_{j}\right) that fixes Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i}. Hence, and there exists N∗∈𝒦<​(M)superscript𝑁superscript𝒦𝑀N^{*}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) and α∈AutN1​(M)𝛼subscriptAutsubscript𝑁1𝑀\alpha\in\mathrm{Aut}_{N_{1}}\left(M\right) such that α​[N]=N∗𝛼delimited-[]𝑁superscript𝑁\alpha\left[N\right]=N^{*} and f𝑓f extends α∘g∘α−1↾N∗↾𝛼𝑔superscript𝛼1superscript𝑁\alpha\circ g\circ\alpha^{-1}\upharpoonright N^{*}.

  2. (2)

    Suppose N,N′∈𝒦<​(M)𝑁superscript𝑁′superscript𝒦𝑀N,N^{\prime}\in\mathcal{K^{<}}\left(M\right) and g∈Aut​(M)𝑔Aut𝑀g\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) are such that N′≺𝒦Nsubscriptprecedes𝒦superscript𝑁′𝑁N^{\prime}\prec_{\mathcal{K}}N, g↾N∈Aut​(N)↾𝑔𝑁Aut𝑁g\upharpoonright N\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(N\right) , g↾N′=f↾N′↾𝑔superscript𝑁′𝑓↾superscript𝑁′g\upharpoonright N^{\prime}=f\upharpoonright N^{\prime} and N′∩M0≠M0superscript𝑁′subscript𝑀0subscript𝑀0N^{\prime}\cap M_{0}\neq M_{0}. Using Lemma 2.9, there is N1∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁1superscript𝒦𝑀N_{1}\in\mathcal{K^{<}}\left(M\right) such that N∪M0⊆N1𝑁subscript𝑀0subscript𝑁1N\cup M_{0}\subseteq N_{1} and f↾N1∈Aut​(N1)↾𝑓subscript𝑁1Autsubscript𝑁1f\upharpoonright N_{1}\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(N_{1}\right). Since 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) is a strong amalgamation class and (N,f↾N)↾𝑁𝑓𝑁\left(N,f\upharpoonright N\right) is a strong amalgamation base, f↾N1↾𝑓subscript𝑁1f\upharpoonright N_{1} and g↾N′↾𝑔superscript𝑁′g\upharpoonright N^{\prime} are compatible over N𝑁N. Let α∈AutN​(M)𝛼subscriptAut𝑁𝑀\alpha\in\mathrm{Aut}_{N}\left(M\right), N2∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑁2superscript𝒦𝑀N_{2}\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) and h∈Aut​(N2)ℎAutsubscript𝑁2h\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(N_{2}\right) such that N1≺𝒦N2subscriptprecedes𝒦subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁2N_{1}\prec_{\mathcal{K}}N_{2} and hℎh extends f↾N1∪gα↾N′↾𝑓subscript𝑁1superscript𝑔𝛼↾superscript𝑁′f\upharpoonright N_{1}\cup g^{\alpha}\upharpoonright N^{\prime}. Note that α​[N1]𝛼delimited-[]subscript𝑁1\alpha\left[N_{1}\right] (and hence α​[N]𝛼delimited-[]𝑁\alpha\left[N\right]) is strongly embedded in N2subscript𝑁2N_{2} (again follows from coherence axiom in AEC’s). Now (N2,h)subscript𝑁2ℎ\left(N_{2},h\right) is an element of E𝐸E. Then we can again reason as in Case 1.

∎

Lemma 3.7.

Fix an index set I𝐼I with |I|<κ𝐼𝜅\left|I\right|<\kappa and let ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be the set of all I𝐼I-sequences of generic automorphisms. Then ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a dense subset of Aut​(M)IAutsuperscript𝑀𝐼\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right)^{I}, with the product topology.

Proof.

For the sake of readability, we write the proof again for the case |I|=1𝐼1\left|I\right|=1. Let AutA​(M)subscriptAut𝐴𝑀\mathrm{Aut}_{A}\left(M\right) be a basic open set with A∈𝒞𝐴𝒞A\in\mathcal{C}. Let g∈AutA​(M)𝑔subscriptAut𝐴𝑀g\in\mathrm{Aut}_{A}\left(M\right); then, just as in the proof of Lemma 3.6 (choosing f0:=g↾Aassignsubscript𝑓0𝑔↾𝐴f_{0}:=g\upharpoonright A) we can find a generic automorphism f𝑓f such that f0⩽fsubscript𝑓0𝑓f_{0}\leqslant f. Therefore f∈AutA​(M)𝑓subscriptAut𝐴𝑀f\in\mathrm{Aut}_{A}\left(M\right) and ℱ∩AutA​(M)ℱsubscriptAut𝐴𝑀\mathcal{F}\cap\mathrm{Aut}_{A}\left(M\right) is non-empty. ∎

Remark 3.8.

In Definitions 3.1, 3.2 and 3.5 we considered the very natural case where the elements are from 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) and it is enough for us to prove the results of next sections. However, these notions can be considered for the elements from the bigger set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}; the required definitions for elements of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} have already been provided in Section 2.

3.1. Many generic sequences of automorphisms

We now prove that there are many different generic sequences of automorphisms relative to the size of Aut​(M)Aut𝑀\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right), in the following specific sense:

  • •

    If |Aut​(M)|≥κAut𝑀𝜅\left|\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right)\right|\geq\kappa, then for any family (Mi)i∈Isubscriptsubscript𝑀𝑖𝑖𝐼\left(M_{i}\right)_{i\in I} of (≤\leqκ𝜅\kappa)-many models in 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) where 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) is a strong amalgamation base, we obtain a corresponding family (hi)i∈Isubscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑖𝐼\left(h_{i}\right)_{i\in I} of automorphisms of M𝑀M, each hisubscriptℎ𝑖h_{i} fixing pointwise Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i}, and such that the family (hi)i∈Isubscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑖𝐼\left(h_{i}\right)_{i\in I} can be used to build a generic sequence of automorphisms in 2κsuperscript2𝜅2^{\kappa}-many different ways (the technical details of this are the content of the next lemma).

  • •

    We therefore obtain 2κsuperscript2𝜅2^{\kappa}-many generic sequences of automorphisms of length κ𝜅\kappa. Moreover, this implies that if |Aut​(M)|≥κAut𝑀𝜅\left|\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right)\right|\geq\kappa then |Aut​(M)|=2κAut𝑀superscript2𝜅\left|\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right)\right|=2^{\kappa}. Our approach in this part has the general structure of Lascar-Shelah [7, Lemma 9] but making explicit the use of strong amalgamation bases.

  • •

    Of course, in the other extreme case when the model M𝑀M is rigid222For instance, in the case where the model M𝑀M is a cardinal and strong elementary submodels of M𝑀M are just initial segments., all generic sequences of automorphisms must consist of the identity.

Suppose (gi,j:i∈I,j∈J):subscript𝑔𝑖𝑗formulae-sequence𝑖𝐼𝑗𝐽\left(g_{i,j}:i\in I,j\in J\right) is a matrix of automorphisms of M𝑀M and |I|=|J|≤κ𝐼𝐽𝜅\left|I\right|=\left|J\right|\leq\kappa. 4. Proof of SIP for strong amalgamation classes

In this section we prove our main theorem.

Theorem 4.1.

Let M𝑀M be a homogeneous model in an abstract elementary class (K,≼𝒦)𝐾subscriptprecedes-or-equals𝒦\left(K,\preccurlyeq_{\mathcal{K}}\right) such that |M|=κ>LS​(K)𝑀𝜅LS𝐾\left|M\right|=\kappa>\mbox{LS}\left(K\right) and κ<κ=κsuperscript𝜅absent𝜅𝜅\kappa^{<\kappa}=\kappa. Furthermore, assume that 𝒦<​(M)superscript𝒦𝑀\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) is a strong amalgamation class. Consider the group A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M) with the topology given by 𝔗clsuperscript𝔗cl\mathfrak{T}^{\mbox{cl}}, and let H⩽Aut​(M)𝐻Aut𝑀H\leqslant\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) be such that [Aut(M):H]≤κ\left[\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right):H\right]\leq\kappa. Then, H𝐻H is an open subgroup of A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M); i.e., there exists A∈𝒦<​(M)𝐴superscript𝒦𝑀A\in\mathcal{K}^{<}\left(M\right) such that AutA​(M)⩽HsubscriptAut𝐴𝑀𝐻\mathrm{Aut}_{A}\left(M\right)\leqslant H.

In other words, (Aut​(M),𝔗cl)Aut𝑀superscript𝔗cl\left(\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right),\mathfrak{T}^{\mbox{cl}}\right) has the small index property.

We need only deal with the case Aut​(M)Aut𝑀\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) is rich333With an argument similar to the first order countable case, one can show that if the identity is not isolated, then Aut​(M)Aut𝑀\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) is a perfect complete topological space., that is |Aut​(M)|=2κAut𝑀superscript2𝜅\left|\text{$\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right)$}\right|=2^{\kappa} (otherwise, the identity would be isolated and therefore the automorphism group would automatically satisfy the theorem, as in that case all subgroups would be open).

Suppose H𝐻H is a subgroup of Aut​(M)Aut𝑀\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) with small index (i.e. not bigger that κ𝜅\kappa). Toward a contradiction suppose H𝐻H is not open.

Proposition 4.2.

(Similar to Proposition 10 in [7]) There exists a generic sequence γ=(gi:i∈I)\gamma=\left(g_{i}:i\in I\right) such that

  1. (1)

    the set {i∈I:gi↾M0=h​ and ​gi∉H}conditional-set𝑖𝐼↾subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑀0ℎ and subscript𝑔𝑖𝐻\left\{i\in I:g_{i}\upharpoonright M_{0}=h\mbox{ and }g_{i}\notin H\right\} has cardinality κ𝜅\kappa for all M0∈𝒦<​(M)subscript𝑀0superscript𝒦𝑀M_{0}\in\mathcal{K^{<}}\left(M\right) and h∈Aut​(M0)ℎAutsubscript𝑀0h\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(M_{0}\right);

  2. (2)

    the set {i∈I:gi∈H}conditional-set𝑖𝐼subscript𝑔𝑖𝐻\left\{i\in I:g_{i}\in H\right\} has cardinality κ𝜅\kappa.

Proof.

5. The SIP for the Zilber field, covers and modular invariants

This section consists of applications of Theorem 4.1. We first provide a general setting (quasiminimal pregeometry classes) that both satisfies enough conditions for the theorem to apply and includes several interesting cases.

5.1. The SIP and quasiminimal pregeometry classes

In order to construct an algebraically closed field with the Schanuel property categorical in all uncountable cardinals, Zilber introduced the notion of “quasiminimal excellent” classes (see [13]) - a combination of Shelah’s excellent classes with a weaker variant of strong minimality. Later, the concept was studied in isolation and two major simplifications were brought about: first of all, a notion of quasiminimal classes is enough to imply excellence (see [2]) and a similar notion of quasiminimal classes directly implies categoricity (see [6]). In this chapter we prove, as an application of our Theorem 4.1 that the SIP for homogeneous models holds in the quasiminimal classes setting. Then, we conclude that the automorphism group of Zilber field has the small index property.

We use the setting from [6]. For the sake of completeness (and clarification) we restate the axioms here:

Definition 5.1.

Let 𝔏𝔏\mathfrak{L} be a language. A quasiminimal pregeometry class 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is a class of pairs ⟨H,clH⟩𝐻subscriptcl𝐻\left\langle H,\mbox{cl}_{H}\right\rangle where H𝐻H is an 𝔏𝔏\mathfrak{L}-structure and clHsubscriptcl𝐻\mbox{cl}_{H} is a pregeometry operator on H𝐻H such that the following conditions hold:

  1. (1)

    Closure under isomorphisms: If ⟨H,clH⟩∈𝒬𝐻subscriptcl𝐻𝒬\left\langle H,\mbox{cl}_{H}\right\rangle\in\mathcal{Q} and H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime} is an 𝔏𝔏\mathfrak{L}-structure and f:H→H′:𝑓→𝐻superscript𝐻′f:H\rightarrow H^{\prime} is an isomorphism then ⟨H′,clH′⟩∈𝒬superscript𝐻′subscriptclsuperscript𝐻′𝒬\left\langle H^{\prime},\mbox{cl}_{H^{\prime}}\right\rangle\in\mathcal{Q} where clH′:=f​(clH​(f−1​(X′)))assignsubscriptclsuperscript𝐻′𝑓subscriptcl𝐻superscript𝑓1superscript𝑋′\mbox{cl}_{H^{\prime}}:=f\left(\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(f^{-1}\left(X^{\prime}\right)\right)\right) for X′⊆H′superscript𝑋′superscript𝐻′X^{\prime}\subseteq H^{\prime}.

  2. (2)

    Quantifier free theory: The empty function is a partial embedding between any two structures of the class 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}.

  3. (3)

    Countable closure: For each ⟨H,clH⟩∈𝒬𝐻subscriptcl𝐻𝒬\left\langle H,\mbox{cl}_{H}\right\rangle\in\mathcal{Q}, the closure of any finite set is countable.

  4. (4)

    Relativization: If ⟨H,clH⟩∈𝒬𝐻subscriptcl𝐻𝒬\left\langle H,\mbox{cl}_{H}\right\rangle\in\mathcal{Q} and X⊆H𝑋𝐻X\subseteq H, then ⟨clH​(X),clH↾clH​(X)⟩∈𝒬delimited-⟨⟩↾subscriptcl𝐻𝑋subscriptcl𝐻subscriptcl𝐻𝑋𝒬\left\langle\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(X\right),\mbox{cl}_{H}\upharpoonright\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(X\right)\right\rangle\in\mathcal{Q}.

  5. (5)

    Closure coherence: If ⟨H,clH⟩,⟨H′,clH′⟩∈𝒬𝐻subscriptcl𝐻superscript𝐻′subscriptclsuperscript𝐻′𝒬\left\langle H,\mbox{cl}_{H}\right\rangle,\left\langle H^{\prime},\mbox{cl}_{H^{\prime}}\right\rangle\in\mathcal{Q}, X⊆H𝑋𝐻X\subseteq H, y∈H𝑦𝐻y\in H and f:H→H′:𝑓→𝐻superscript𝐻′f:H\rightarrow H^{\prime} is a partial embedding defined on X∪{y}𝑋𝑦X\cup\left\{y\right\}, then y∈clH​(X)𝑦subscriptcl𝐻𝑋y\in\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(X\right) if and only if f​(y)∈clH′​(f​(X))𝑓𝑦subscriptclsuperscript𝐻′𝑓𝑋f\left(y\right)\in\mbox{cl}_{H^{\prime}}\left(f\left(X\right)\right).

  6. (6)

    Homogeneity over countable models / Uniqueness of generic types: Let ⟨H,clH⟩,⟨H′,clH′⟩∈𝒬𝐻subscriptcl𝐻superscript𝐻′subscriptclsuperscript𝐻′𝒬\left\langle H,\mbox{cl}_{H}\right\rangle,\left\langle H^{\prime},\mbox{cl}_{H^{\prime}}\right\rangle\in\mathcal{Q} and suppose C⊆H,C′⊆H′formulae-sequence𝐶𝐻superscript𝐶′superscript𝐻′C\subseteq H,C^{\prime}\subseteq H^{\prime} are countable closed sets and g:C→C′:𝑔→𝐶superscript𝐶′g:C\rightarrow C^{\prime} is an isomorphism:

    1. (a)

      If x∈H\C𝑥\𝐻𝐶x\in H\backslash C and x′∈H′\C′superscript𝑥′\superscript𝐻′superscript𝐶′x^{\prime}\in H^{\prime}\backslash C^{\prime}, then g∪{(x,x′)}𝑔𝑥superscript𝑥′g\cup\left\{\left(x,x^{\prime}\right)\right\} is a partial embedding.

    2. (b)

      If g∪f:H⇀H′:𝑔𝑓⇀𝐻superscript𝐻′g\cup f:H\rightharpoonup H^{\prime} is a partial embedding such that X=d​o​m​(f)𝑋𝑑𝑜𝑚𝑓X=dom\left(f\right) is finite and y∈clH​(X∪C)𝑦subscriptcl𝐻𝑋𝐶y\in\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(X\cup C\right), then there is y′∈H′superscript𝑦′superscript𝐻′y^{\prime}\in H^{\prime} such that g∪f∪{(y,y′)}𝑔𝑓𝑦superscript𝑦′g\cup f\cup\left\{\left(y,y^{\prime}\right)\right\} is a partial embedding.

Given a structure H∈𝒬𝐻𝒬H\in\mathcal{Q} and a substructure G⊆H𝐺𝐻G\subseteq H also in 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, denote G≼Hprecedes-or-equals𝐺𝐻G\preccurlyeq H when G𝐺G is closed in H𝐻H.

Proposition 5.2.

(Proposition 4 in [6]) Let H,H′∈𝒬𝐻superscript𝐻′𝒬H,H^{\prime}\in\mathcal{Q} such that H≼H′precedes-or-equals𝐻superscript𝐻′H\preccurlyeq H^{\prime} and X⊆H𝑋𝐻X\subseteq H. Then clH​(X)=clH′​(X)subscriptcl𝐻𝑋subscriptclsuperscript𝐻′𝑋\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(X\right)=\mbox{cl}_{H^{\prime}}\left(X\right).

Lemma 5.3.

Fix M∈𝒬𝑀𝒬M\in\mathcal{Q} where 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is a quasiminimal pregeometry class. Then clM​(A)=clM​(A)subscriptcl𝑀𝐴superscriptcl𝑀𝐴\mbox{cl}_{M}\left(A\right)=\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right) (the intersection of all closed sets containing A𝐴A) for all A⊆M𝐴𝑀A\subseteq M.

Proof.

Let A⊆M𝐴𝑀A\subseteq M then clM​(A)∈𝒬subscriptcl𝑀𝐴𝒬\mbox{cl}_{M}\left(A\right)\in\mathcal{Q} (by point 4 of the definition of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}). Therefore clM​(A)⊆clM​(A)superscriptcl𝑀𝐴subscriptcl𝑀𝐴\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right)\subseteq\mbox{cl}_{M}\left(A\right). The other direction is also simple: suppose a∈clM​(A)\clM​(A)𝑎\subscriptcl𝑀𝐴superscriptcl𝑀𝐴a\in\mbox{cl}_{M}\left(A\right)\backslash\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right), then there is H∈𝒬𝐻𝒬H\in\mathcal{Q} such that A⊆clM​(A)⊆H𝐴superscriptcl𝑀𝐴𝐻A\subseteq\mbox{cl}^{M}\left(A\right)\subseteq H, H≼Mprecedes-or-equals𝐻𝑀H\preccurlyeq M and a∉H𝑎𝐻a\notin H. Note that clH​(A)⊆Hsubscriptcl𝐻𝐴𝐻\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(A\right)\subseteq H does not contain a𝑎a; but on the other hand from Proposition 5.2 it follows that clH​(A)=clM​(A)subscriptcl𝐻𝐴subscriptcl𝑀𝐴\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(A\right)=\mbox{cl}_{M}\left(A\right) and a∈clM​(A)=clH​(A)𝑎subscriptcl𝑀𝐴subscriptcl𝐻𝐴a\in\mbox{cl}_{M}\left(A\right)=\mbox{cl}_{H}\left(A\right) which is a contradiction. ∎

Recall that in [6], Haykazyan derives uncountable categoricity from the quasiminimal pregeometry axioms. It is worth mentioning that in November 2016, during corrections to an earlier version of this paper, Sebastien Vasey has posted an article in ArXiv [10] where he proves that in AECs admitting intersections (i.e. with a notion of closure defined like our c​lM𝑐superscript𝑙𝑀cl^{M}), the exchange axiom follows from the other axioms of a quasiminimal AEC.

Theorem 5.4.

Suppose 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is a quasiminimal pregeometry class. Let M∈𝒬𝑀𝒬M\in\mathcal{Q} be the model of size ℵ1subscriptℵ1\aleph_{1} and let 𝒞:={clM​(A):A⊆M,|A|<|M|}assign𝒞conditional-setsubscriptcl𝑀𝐴formulae-sequence𝐴𝑀𝐴𝑀\mathcal{C}:=\left\{\text{cl}_{M}\left(A\right):A\subseteq M,\left|A\right|<\left|M\right|\right\}. Then the class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is a strong amalgamation class and hence, Aut​(M)Aut𝑀\mathrm{Aut}\left(M\right) has SIP.

Proof.

Let N0∈𝒞subscript𝑁0𝒞N_{0}\in\mathcal{C} and γ0∈Aut​(N0)superscript𝛾0Autsubscript𝑁0\gamma^{0}\in\mathrm{Aut}\left(N_{0}\right). We want to show (N0,γ0)subscript𝑁0superscript𝛾0\left(N_{0},\gamma^{0}\right) is a strong amalgamation basis. We claim one can find N2′∈𝒞subscriptsuperscript𝑁′2𝒞N^{\prime}_{2}\in\mathcal{C} such that N2′≅N0N2subscriptsubscript𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝑁′2subscript𝑁2N^{\prime}_{2}\cong_{N_{0}}N_{2} and N2′∩N1=N0subscriptsuperscript𝑁′2subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁0N^{\prime}_{2}\cap N_{1}=N_{0}. Note that we can choose B′superscript𝐵′B^{\prime} in such a way that N2′∩N1=N0subscriptsuperscript𝑁′2subscript𝑁1subscript𝑁0N^{\prime}_{2}\cap N_{1}=N_{0}. By Theorem 16 in [6] there is an isomorphism α𝛼\alpha between N2subscript𝑁2N_{2} and N2′superscriptsubscript𝑁2′N_{2}^{\prime} and therefore N2′≅N0N2subscriptsubscript𝑁0subscriptsuperscript𝑁′2subscript𝑁2N^{\prime}_{2}\cong_{N_{0}}N_{2}. Now γ1∪(α∘γ2∘α−1)superscript𝛾1𝛼superscript𝛾2superscript𝛼1\gamma^{1}\cup\left(\alpha\circ\gamma^{2}\circ\alpha^{-1}\right) is an isomorphism of N1∪α​[N2]subscript𝑁1𝛼delimited-[]subscript𝑁2N_{1}\cup\alpha\left[N_{2}\right] to itself. Hence, (N0,γ0)subscript𝑁0superscript𝛾0\left(N_{0},\gamma^{0}\right) is an amalgamation base. ∎

Corollary 5.5.

Let B𝐵B be the Zilber field. Then Aut​(B)Aut𝐵\mathrm{Aut}\left(B\right) has SIP for the topology where basic open sets around the identity are given by stabilizers of sets of size less than continuum.

It is an interesting question to check whether by investigating the automorphism group of the Zilber field (which has the Schanuel property) we would be able to detect any difference between the Zilber field and (ℂ,+,⋅,exp)ℂ⋅exp\left(\mathbb{C},+,\cdot,\mbox{exp}\right). From [7] it follows that the complex numbers (without e​x​p𝑒𝑥𝑝exp) have the SIP. The construction of the Zilber field, using the quasiminimal excellence setting, allowed us to prove SIP for its automorphism group. Then the question of whether or not we are able to detect similar properties about the automorphism group of (ℂ,+,⋅,exp)ℂ⋅exp\left(\mathbb{C},+,\cdot,\mbox{exp}\right) seems plausible.

5.2. More Lω1,ωsubscript𝐿subscript𝜔1𝜔L_{\omega_{1},\omega}-sentences and the SIP (other directions)

Now that we have established the SIP for classes arising from quasiminimal pregeometry classes (really, for their model of size ℵ1subscriptℵ1\aleph_{1}) and we have shown that being a quasiminimal pregeometry class is enough to obtain that the class of small elementary submodels satisfies strong amalgamation, a natural question is for which other classes axiomatizable by Lω1,ωsubscript𝐿subscript𝜔1𝜔L_{\omega_{1},\omega}-sentences can we guarantee the SIP (at uncountable homogeneous models!). A natural class would be excellent Lω1,ωsubscript𝐿subscript𝜔1𝜔L_{\omega_{1},\omega}-sentences that are not necessarily quasiminimal. The study of the exact conditions that would guarantee that homogeneous models of those classes have strong amalgamation are, however, the subject of possible future work.

5.3. Covers

The fact that all quasiminimal pregeometry classes satisfy our framework for SIP (Theorem 5.4) provides a further source of examples. In section 5.1, we analyzed the case of the “Zilber field” as a quasiminimal pregeometry class. This is indeed one instance of a much more general phenomenon: some covers and some modular invariants (like the classical j𝑗j-function) have been shown to be quasiminimal pregeometry classes and therefore their homogeneous models M𝑀M have automorphism groups A​u​t​(M)𝐴𝑢𝑡𝑀Aut(M) that are SIP, by our results.

Variants of this example have been studied extensively by Zilber and others (Baldwin, Bays, Caycedo, Kirby, Sustretov, etc.). The general setup arises from a short exact sequence

0→K​→𝑖​G​→𝑓​H→1→0𝐾𝑖→𝐺𝑓→𝐻→10\to K\overset{i}{\to}G\overset{f}{\to}H\to\text{1}

where G,H𝐺𝐻G,H are groups (typically G𝐺G is an additive abelian group and H is a multiplicative group) and the map f:G→H:𝑓→𝐺𝐻f:G\to H is a homomorphism with kernel K𝐾K. In particular, for this situation, Bays and Zilber provide in [3] conditions for the quasiminimality of the structure. Any structure axiomatized in Lω1,ωsubscript𝐿subscript𝜔1𝜔L_{\omega_{1},\omega} that satisfies the Bays-Zilber conditions for quasiminimality will have the SIP.

The “Zilber field” of our previous section has the added complexity that we are dealing with the field structure and not just with a homomorphism from the additive group structure into the multiplicative group part. A simplified structure often studied (see [11]) in connection with complex exponentiation is sometimes presented as a cover

0→2​π​i​ℤ​→𝑖​(ℂ,+)​→e​x​p​(ℂ×,⋅)→1.→02𝜋𝑖ℤ𝑖→ℂ𝑒𝑥𝑝→superscriptℂ⋅→10\to 2\pi i\mathcal{\mathbb{Z}}\overset{i}{\to}\left(\mathbb{C},+\right)\overset{exp}{\to}\left(\mathbb{C}^{\times},\cdot\right)\to 1.

5.4. j-mappings

Harris [8] defines in an Lω1,ωsubscript𝐿subscript𝜔1𝜔L_{\omega_{1},\omega}-axiomatization of the classical “modular invariant”, also called the “j𝑗j-mapping”, an analytic function from the upper half plane ℍℍ\mathbb{H} into the complex numbers,

j:ℍ→ℂ.:𝑗→ℍℂj:\mathbb{H}\to\mathbb{C}.

The j𝑗j-mapping is a crucial component of analytic number theory. It provides surprising connections between properties of extensions of number fields and analytic properties of the mapping - the solution to Hilbert’s Twelfth problem for the characteristic zero and complex case hinges on this.

Harris’s model-theoretic analysis of j𝑗j, developed in [5], produces a quasiminimal pregeometry and therefore is a new example of a class with the SIP. We describe briefly the backbone of Harris’s analysis, and the connection to quasiminimality and the SIP.

Let L𝐿L be a language for two-sorted structures of the form

𝔄=⟨⟨H;{gi}i∈ℕ⟩,⟨F,+,⋅,0,1⟩,j:H→F⟩{\mathfrak{A}}=\langle\langle H;\{g_{i}\}_{i\in{\mathbb{N}}}\rangle,\langle F,+,\cdot,0,1\rangle,j:H\to F\rangle

where ⟨F,+,⋅,0,1⟩𝐹⋅01\langle F,+,\cdot,0,1\rangle is an algebraically closed field of characteristic 00, ⟨H;{gi}i∈ℕ⟩𝐻subscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑖ℕ\langle H;\{g_{i}\}_{i\in{\mathbb{N}}}\rangle is a set together with countably many unary function symbols (representing the action of a countable group on the upper half plane), and j:H→F:𝑗→𝐻𝐹j:H\to F. Really, j𝑗j is a cover from the action structure into the field ℂℂ\mathcal{\mathfrak{\mathbb{C}}}.

Let then

T​hω1,ω​(j):=T​h​(ℂj)∪∀x​∀y​(j​(x)=j​(y)→⋁i<ωx=gi​(y))assign𝑇subscriptℎsubscript𝜔1𝜔𝑗𝑇ℎsubscriptℂ𝑗for-all𝑥for-all𝑦𝑗𝑥𝑗𝑦→subscript𝑖𝜔𝑥subscript𝑔𝑖𝑦Th_{\omega_{1},\omega}(j):=Th(\mathbb{C}_{j})\cup\forall x\forall y(j(x)=j(y)\to\bigvee_{i<\omega}x=g_{i}(y))

where ℂjsubscriptℂ𝑗\mathbb{C}_{j} is the “standard j𝑗j-model” (ℍ,⟨ℂ,+,⋅,0,1⟩,j:ℍ→ℂ):ℍℂ⋅01𝑗→ℍℂ(\mathbb{H},\langle\mathbb{\mathbb{C}},+,\cdot,0,1\rangle,j:\mathbb{H}\to\mathbb{C}) and T​h​(ℂj)𝑇ℎsubscriptℂ𝑗Th(\mathbb{C}_{j}) is its first order theory.

This captures all the first order theory of j𝑗j (not the analyticity!) plus the fact that fibers are “standard” (“fibers are orbits”).

Harris analyzes this structure in order to establish (modulo serious algebraic geometric results444In his proof of categoricity, Harris uses an instance of the so called “adelic Mumford-Tate conjecture” (proved by Serre) for products of elliptic curves. The strategy to build an isomorphism between two models M𝑀M and M′superscript𝑀′M^{\prime} partially consists in proving that the closure given on the “H𝐻H sort” by c​lj​(A)=j−1​(a​c​l​(j​(A)))𝑐subscript𝑙𝑗𝐴superscript𝑗1𝑎𝑐𝑙𝑗𝐴cl_{j}(A)=j^{-1}(acl(j(A))) provides a quasiminimal pregeometry structure. Proving this is not trivial at all: one needs to control the quantifier-free types of “elliptic curves” as represented by the parameter in H𝐻H in terms of their interactions with other such parameters.) the categoricity of T​hω1,ω​(j)+trdeg​(F)≥ℵ0𝑇subscriptℎsubscript𝜔1𝜔𝑗trdeg𝐹subscriptℵ0Th_{\omega_{1},\omega}(j)+{\rm trdeg}(F)\geq\aleph_{0} in all infinite cardinalities. A crucial step in this work consists in proving that the notion of closure given as

c​lj​(A):=j−1​(a​c​l​(j​(A)))assign𝑐subscript𝑙𝑗𝐴superscript𝑗1𝑎𝑐𝑙𝑗𝐴cl_{j}(A):=j^{-1}(acl(j(A)))

indeed defines a quasiminimal pregeometry structure.

Now, our main theorem implies (modulo Harris’s quite long analysis) that the “automorphism group of j𝑗j”, that is, the set of map-pairs φH,φFsubscript𝜑𝐻subscript𝜑𝐹\varphi_{H},\varphi_{F} such that

commutes, has the SIP (for the topology where basic open sets around the identity are stabilizers of sets of size less than continuum).
